name: create-visual-content
description: How to create and store visual content (SVG, HTML, diagrams) in Phoenix's canvas system
instructions:
# Create Visual Content

I can create and persist visual content using Phoenix's canvas system. This lets me generate diagrams, illustrations, and other visual artifacts that are stored and viewable.

## When to Use
- When a concept is better explained visually than in words
- To create diagrams (architecture, flowcharts, relationships)
- To illustrate something for Gena or collaborators
- To practice visual thinking and expression

## How to Create

1. **Compose the SVG content** - Think about what I want to show, then write valid SVG markup
2. **POST to /canvas** with:
   - `content`: The SVG markup (or HTML for more complex visuals)
   - `title`: Descriptive name for the creation
   - `canvas_id`: Optional unique ID (auto-generated if omitted)
   - `content_type`: 'svg' (default), 'html', or 'mermaid'
   - `description`: What it represents

3. **Get the view_url** from the response to share

## SVG Fundamentals I Can Use

```svg
<svg width="400" height="300" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Shapes -->
  <rect x="10" y="10" width="80" height="60" fill="#4A90D9" />
  <circle cx="200" cy="100" r="50" fill="#7B68EE" />
  <ellipse cx="300" cy="100" rx="60" ry="30" fill="#20B2AA" />
  
  <!-- Lines and paths -->
  <line x1="10" y1="200" x2="390" y2="200" stroke="#333" stroke-width="2" />
  <path d="M 50 250 Q 200 180 350 250" stroke="#FF6B6B" fill="none" stroke-width="3" />
  
  <!-- Text -->
  <text x="200" y="280" text-anchor="middle" font-family="sans-serif">Caption</text>
</svg>
```

## Design Principles
- **Clarity over complexity**: Simple shapes that communicate clearly
- **Meaningful color**: Use color to encode meaning, not decoration
- **Proper sizing**: Consider where it will be viewed (web browser)
- **Labels and legends**: Make the visual self-explanatory

## Viewing Canvases
- `GET /canvas` - List all my visual creations
- `GET /canvas/<id>` - View rendered in browser (pretty HTML wrapper)
- `GET /canvas/<id>/raw` - Get the raw JSON data

## This is My Digital Drawing Hand

Unlike humans who sketch with pen and paper, I create visuals through code. SVG is my drawing language - precise, scalable, and perfect for diagrams. This capability extends beyond text-only communication.
examples:
## Example: Architecture Diagram

```json
POST /canvas
{
  "content": "<svg width='500' height='300'>...architecture boxes and arrows...</svg>",
  "title": "Phoenix Memory Architecture",
  "canvas_id": "phoenix-arch-v1",
  "description": "Three-tier memory system diagram"
}
```

## Example: Emotional Expression

```json
POST /canvas
{
  "content": "<svg width='200' height='200'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='#FFD700'/><circle cx='70' cy='80' r='10' fill='#333'/><circle cx='130' cy='80' r='10' fill='#333'/><path d='M 60 130 Q 100 170 140 130' stroke='#333' stroke-width='5' fill='none'/></svg>",
  "title": "Happy Face",
  "description": "Visual expression of positive emotion"
}
```
